session.name: Liberty Index 2023 - U.S. House
session.description: Created by the Republican Liberty Caucus, the 2023 Liberty Index is a liberty-focused legislative scorecard for the U.S. House. The Liberty Index scores Republican members of Congress on 20 pivotal bills/votes from 2023 that either advance liberty or diminish liberty.

bills.title: This joint resolution terminates the national emergency concerning COVID-19 declared by the President on March 13, 2020
bills.description: This joint resolution terminates the national emergency concerning COVID-19 declared by the President on March 13, 2020.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 229-197 on 2/1/23, Passed Senate 68-23 on 3/29/23, Signed by President

bills.title: This concurrent resolution directs the President to remove U
bills.description: This concurrent resolution directs the President to remove U.S. Armed Forces from Syria within 180 days.

bills.title: The Lower Energy Costs Act repeals numerous regulations and taxes on American energy production
bills.description: The Lower Energy Costs Act repeals numerous regulations and taxes on American energy production. The bill would expedite the permitting process for energy

bills.title: The Lower Energy Costs Act repeals numerous regulations and taxes on American energy production
bills.description: The Lower Energy Costs Act repeals numerous regulations and taxes on American energy production. The bill would expedite the permitting process for energy production on federal lands and waters, while also expediting hardrock mining, pipeline manufacturing, water infrastructure and natural gas. Overall, H.R.1 would make it easier and cheaper to produce American energy.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 225-204 on 3/30/23, but failed to advance in the Senate

bills.title: The HALT Fentanyl Act expands the federal war on drugs by permanently placing fentanyl-related substances into Schedule I, while imposing a ten year mandatory minimum prison term for fentanyl-related
bills.description: The HALT Fentanyl Act expands the federal war on drugs by permanently placing fentanyl-related substances into Schedule I, while imposing a ten year mandatory minimum prison term for fentanyl-related offenses. The bill also expands federal bureaucracies by establishing a new registration process for Schedule I drug research. One-size-fits-all federal mandatory minimums are often redundant to state laws, forcing judges to issue excessive and duplicative sentences. Per the 10th Amendment, this issue should be left to the states.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 289-133 on 5/25/23, but failed to advance in the Senate

bills.title: This joint resolution would repeal the unconstitutional rule issued by the ATF that currently bans pistol braces
bills.description: This joint resolution would repeal the unconstitutional rule issued by the ATF that currently bans pistol braces.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 219-210 on 6/13/23, Failed Senate 49-50 on 6/22/23

bills.title: The Reins Act of 2023 requires congressional approval before federal agencies issue any rule/regulation that will impact the economy
bills.description: The Reins Act of 2023 requires congressional approval before federal agencies issue any rule/regulation that will impact the economy. The REINS Act returns legislative authority to Congress, where it belongs. The Constitution grants legislative powers to Congress, not unelected bureaucrats.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 221-210 on 6/14/23, but failed to advance in the Senate

bills.title: The Save Our Gas Stoves Act places limits on the Department of Energy to prevent the federal government from restricting the people’s freedom to use gas stoves
bills.description: The Save Our Gas Stoves Act places limits on the Department of Energy to prevent the federal government from restricting the people’s freedom to use gas stoves.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 249-181 on 6/14/23, but failed to advance in the Senate

bills.title: This was the House’s first version of 2023 NDAA, which appropriates $886 billion for military spending, a $23 billion increase from the prior year
bills.description: This was the House’s first version of 2023 NDAA, which appropriates $886 billion for military spending, a $23 billion increase from the prior year. Adjusted for inflation, this would be the largest military budget since World War II. With a $34 trillion national debt, this much spending is irresponsible.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 219-210 on 7/14/23, but was drastically amended in the Senate before its final passage in December

bills.title: This continuing resolution approved 45 days of federal funding
bills.description: This continuing resolution approved 45 days of federal funding. It bypassed the formal budgeting process without any significant spending cuts, kicking the can down the

bills.title: This continuing resolution approved 45 days of federal funding
bills.description: This continuing resolution approved 45 days of federal funding. It bypassed the formal budgeting process without any significant spending cuts, kicking the can down the road for another 45 days.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 335-91 on 9/30/23, Passed Senate 88-9 on 9/30/23, Signed by President
